title: Stocks Close Lower After S&P 500, Nasdaq Records; S&P 500 pauses rally as investors assess gross-domestic-product data, weekly jobless figures
text:
Stocks have pushed higher lately, supported by broad gains across everything from financial and industrial stocks to technology shares.

Heading into the end of the week, money managers say their focus is largely on comments expected from Federal Reserve officials on Friday that could offer cues on the central bank's plans for tapering stimulus measures. Some investors are betting that the Fed may slow those plans if there are signs that the economic recovery is faltering.

Fresh data Thursday showed that theU.S. economy grew 6.6% on an annualized basis in the second quarter, an upward revision from the initial print last month. Meanwhile, weekly jobless claimscame in at 353,000, a slight increase from the previous week's pandemic low. Economists were expecting the level to be relatively unchanged.

"Risk assets have done well this last week and as we go into the Fed event, there is some profit taking," said Shaniel Ramjee, multiasset fund manager at Pictet Asset Management. "No one can honestly say they know what's going to happen, this uncertainty will put some reduction on risk."

Among individual stocks, Salesforce.com rose 4.8% after the business-software company reported a jump in quarterly salesand raised its full-year outlook on Wednesday evening.

Home-goods retailer Williams-Sonoma jumped 11% after increasing its quarterly dividend and share-buyback program.

Software developer Autodesk fell 8.2% after it said it expects third-quarter revenue and profit levels that came in below analysts' estimates.

Zoom Video Communications added 1.8% after an equity research analyst at Morgan Stanley raised their rating on the stock.

Peloton Interactive, Gap and Dell Technologies are scheduled to post quarterly results after markets close.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 dropped 0.3%.

Among European equities, Deutsche Bank's DWS Group tumbled 14% following a report by The Wall Street Journal that the asset management firm is being probed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and federal prosecutors over sustainability claims.

In Asia, most major benchmarks declined by the close of trading. The Shanghai Composite Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index retreated over 1%.

South Korea's Kospi Index slid 0.6%. The nation's central bank raised its key policy rate, becoming the first major Asian one to do so since the pandemic began. The Korean won depreciated 0.3% against the dollar.

Write to Anna Hirtenstein at anna.hirtenstein@wsj.com and Akane Otani at akane.otani@wsj.com
